questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the serological markers in osteoporosis?
questions.solution: Reference:Manish kumar varshney 1stedition page no-72

questions.text: Named fractures match the following:
questions.solution:
March fracture: Fatigue fracture of the shaft of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal.

Bennett's fracture-dislocation: It is an oblique, intra-articular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with subluxation of the trapezio-metacarpal joint

Jone's fracture: Avulsion fracture of the base of the 5th metatarsal.

Boxers' fracture: It is a ventrally displaced fracture through the neck of the 5th metacarpal, usually occurs in boxers

Reference:Essentials orthopedics by Maheshwari 7thedition page no 3

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came to the emergency following injury to the shoulder, there was difficulty in the movement of the arm with swelling. On clinical examination, there was tenderness and numbness over the lateral aspect of the upper arm. What would the associated injury be?
questions.solution:
Based on history patient has sustained injury over shoulder and he has tenderness and numbness over lateral aspect of the arm.so here deltoid muscle is situated.so he must have injury over deltoid muscle.

CAUSES of AXILLARY NERVE INJURY

  • Shoulder dislocation (m\c)
  • Fracture neck of humerus
  • Iatrogenic
  • IM injections

CLINICAL FEATURES OF AXILLARY NERVE INJURY

  • Deltoid paralysis
    • Loss of shoulder abduction (15-90 degree)
  • Teres minor palsy- aymptomatic
  • Sensory loss:
    • Upper lateral arm
    • Regimental badge sign

Here out of all four-options deltoid muscle is situated at lateral aspect of upper arm.

Reference:ESSENTIAL ORTHOPEDICS BY MAHESHWARI 7THEDITION PAGE NO 91

questions.text:
Identify the site at which nerve injured would cause inability to flex DIP of fourth and fifth digit and unable to hold paper between fingers.
Proper marking of image
questions.solution:
Here patient is unable to perform card test-patient is unable to hold paper between fingers so patient have palmar interossei muscle weakness which are supplied by ulnar nerve and here ulnar nerve is situated just behind medial epicondyle of humerus.

Rest all options are incorrect as

  • At a site axillary nerve is situated at neck of humerus site.
  • At b site radial nerve is situated at midshaft humerus.

For ulnar nerve remember :-

A-adductor pollicus

B-book test - for adductor pollicis

C-card test - to check palmar interossei

E-egawa test - to check dorsal interossei

F-froment sign.

Nerve injury and location of injury

Reference:Maheshwari ortho 7thedition page no 67

questions.text: Which of the following is the last symptom to develop in compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
The limbs contain muscles in compartments enclosed by bones, fascia and interosseous membrane. A rise in pressure within these compartments due to any reason may jeopardize the blood supply to the muscles and nerves within the compartment, resulting in what is known as “compartment syndrome

Compartment syndrome can be diagnosed early by high index of suspicion. Excessive pain, not relieved with usual doses of analgesics, in a patient with an injury known to cause compartment syndrome must raise an alarm in the mind of the treating doctor. Injuries with a high risk of developing compartment syndrome are as follows:

  • Supracondylar fracture of the humerus
  • Forearm bone fractures
  • Closed tibial fractures
  • Crush injuries to leg and forearm.

Diagnosis of compartment syndrome

  • Normotensive patient
    • Compartment pressure >30 mmHg
  • Hypotensive patient

Delta P (diastolic BP - compartment pressure) <30mmHg

5 p's of compartment syndrome

Pain out of proportion to exam, paresthesias, pallor, pulselessness, paralysis.

Paralysis is last symptom to develop in compartment syndrome.

Reference:Essential orthopedics by Maheshwari 7thedition page no 48.

questions.text:
An orthopaedic surgeon wants to give a plaster for Colles fracture. Arrange the following steps in order.
a. Traction
b. Ulnar deviation
c. Palmar flexion
d. POP
questions.solution:
6 classical deficits in colles fracture are:

  • Dorsal tilt/displacement
  • Lateral tilt/displacement
  • Impaction
  • Supination
Sequence of correction explained below technique.
Technique of closed manipulation:
The muscles of forearm must be relaxed, either by general or regional anaesthesia. The surgeon grasps the injured hand as if he was 'shaking hands'.
The first step is to disimpact the fragments which have often been driven together. This is achieved by firm longitudinal traction to the hand against the counter-traction by an assistant who grasps the arm above the flexed elbow. Some displacements are corrected by traction alone.
 The surgeon now presses the distal fragment into palmar flexion and ulnar deviation using the thumb of his other hand. As this is done, the patient's hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion and ulnar deviation. A
Plaster cast is applied extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, maintaining the wrist in palmar flexion and ulnar deviation. This is Colles' cast.

Reference: Essential orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition page no 110.

questions.text: What is the next step of management in posterior hip joint dislocation?
questions.solution:
• Hip joint dislocation are reduced closely first under short general anaesthesia. If it cannot be reduced using close reduction and if associated with acetabular fracture then open reduction is required.
  • Hip dislocation with or without acetabular or femoral head fracture is an emergency and must be reduced as early as possible.
  • Most of the times close reduction under general anesthesia is possible. Many methods of close reduction have been described like Allis maneuver, Biglows maneuver (leverage method, can reduce both anterior and posterior dislocations but not used due to high risk of femoral neck fractures), Stimsons gravity method and Modified East Baltimore lift.
  • Allis maneuver is the most commonly used method for closed reduction of hip dislocation. Once a stable closed reduction is achieved, a temporary skin traction can be given for soft tissue healing and gradually the patient can be mobilized.
  • However, if a closed reduction fails (interposed labrum etc., or incarcinated bone fragments) patient should be urgently posted for an open reduction. Patients with concomitant femoral neck or head fractures also usually require primary open reduction.

Reference:Fundamentals of orthopedics by mohindra and jain page no-101

questions.text: In an open fracture, which of the following are true, except?
questions.solution:
• Internal fixation is not required on emergency basis in cases of open fractures.
  • In cases of open fracture first fracture should be stabilized with external fixator and wound should be debrided.
  • Once wound gets healed and infection is cleared thereafter open reduction and internal fixation is done.
  • For open fractures gustilo and Anderson classification is used for grading.

Option a) compartment syndrome is more common in closed fracture

Option b) immediate debridement should be done in open fractures to reduce conatamination of the wound

Option c) tibial fractures are commonest for open fractures, stress fractures, fracture nonunion.

Reference:Anderson JT, Gustilo RB. Orthopedics clinics of North America, 1980; 11:56
